p: In an effort to characterize the biological activity of M. spicata essential oil, the antimicrobial activity of the essential oil was examined in the present study. Interestingly, reports from literature on the association between the essential oil phytochemical composition and its antimicrobial activity are found to be in great consistency with the findings of the present study. In particular, oxygenated monoterpenes were evidently reported as potent antimicrobial agent in the composition of several essential oils [ 42]. In addition, 1,8-cineole and sesquiterpenes were shown to exhibit considerable antimicrobial activity against a wide range of Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria [ 42, 43]. However, as essential oils contain multiple components, their antimicrobial activities are rather due to additive, synergistic or antagonistic effects of the individual constituents.
